docs.lead_paragraph: For decades shrewd politicians leveraged Brookhaven's booming population and sprawling acreage on Long Island into a Republican powerhouse with statewide reach. Some also exploited the town, lining their pockets in periodic scandals that earned it the unsavory nickname Crookhaven. But the town has ceased being a safe haven for scoundrels. A new Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, a Democrat, cracked down on corruption, indicting a score of officials and contractors and convicting most of them.

headline.main: With Republican Party in Shambles, Change Is in the Air

docs.snippet: Several political professionals predict that Democrats will score their biggest inroads at Town Hall in three decades in Brookhaven.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush said Friday that he was disappointed with the January date set by Senate Republican leaders for hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. Mr. Bush had called for hearings to be held before Christmas. A fast timetable would have limited the opportunity for liberal groups to rally opposition to confirmation, perhaps helping the president claim a big victory at a time when polls show that his popularity has plunged.

headline.main: Hearing Date for Alito Leaves Bush Disappointed

docs.snippet: President Bush said Friday that he was disappointed with the January date set by Senate Republican leaders for hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr.     Mr. Bush had called for hearings to be held before Christmas. A...

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Greenwald's ''Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price'' is not ''Fahrenheit 9/11.'' There are no goofy takeoffs of old television series. You won't see H. Lee Scott Jr., the chief executive of Wal-Mart, the largest retailer on the planet, practicing his golf swing or making revealing comments on camera. He doesn't have to. Mr. Greenwald's film features plenty of star witnesses, many of them former employees. Weldon Nicholson, a store-manager trainer for 17 years, says that when Wal-Mart came into a new town, management people would scan the stores along Main Street and make a game of predicting how long it would take each business to close.

headline.main: A Look Inside the Outsize Company That Is the Biggest Retailer on the Planet

docs.abstract: Anita Gates reviews documentary movie Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price, directed by Robert Greenwald; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Robert Greenwald's documentary makes a devastating case against the largest retailer on the planet.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: WAL-MART: THE HIGH COST OF LOW PRICE (MOVIE)

docs.lead_paragraph: Productivity growth nearly doubled in the third quarter as labor costs fell, the government reported yesterday. The data, which showed that the economy was growing at a strong clip without signs of widespread inflation, surprised many analysts. Productivity, which is calculated by dividing output by hours worked, rose at an annual pace of 4.1 percent from July through September, up from 2.1 percent in the second quarter, according to the Labor Department. Output jumped 4.2 percent, and hours worked edged up 0.1 percent.

headline.main: Productivity Growth Nearly Doubled in the Third Quarter

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports productivity rose at annual pace of 4.1 percent from July through September, up from 2.1 percent in second quarter; unit labor costs fell 0.5 percent from second quarter, after increasing 1.8 percent in second quarter; hourly compensation was up 3.6 percent, but adjusted for inflation it was down 1.4 percent from second quarter; initial claims for unemployment insurance fell by 8,000 last week, to 323,000; Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing index rose to 60, from 53.3 month before; Commerce Department says factory orders fell by 1.7 percent in September (M)
docs.snippet: The data, which showed that the economy was growing at a strong clip without signs of widespread inflation, surprised many analysts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The board that writes the accounting regulations for American companies is scheduled to vote next week on whether to revise the rule for pensions. The current rule, issued in 1985, has been criticized for distorting corporate financial reports. Some investors have said that the rule allows companies to project, at the beginning of each year, how much money their pension investments are likely to earn, then factor that amount into their bottom lines at the end of the year, no matter what the real performance was.

headline.main: Accounting Board to Vote on Pension Rule

docs.abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board is scheduled to vote Nov 11 on whether to revise rule for pensions; current rule has been criticized for distorting financial reports (S)
docs.snippet: The board that writes the accounting regulations for American companies is scheduled to vote next week on whether to revise the rule for pensions.

docs.lead_paragraph: Louis A. deBottari, a 78-year-old retired aerospace worker with ample drug coverage in his health plan, recently opened an envelope from Boeing, hoping to be reassured. The notice, sent to about 100,000 Boeing retirees and their dependents, discussed the new Medicare drug insurance program that begins in January and what it means for retirees already covered by the company's health plan.

headline.main: A Drug Benefit Conundrum; Retirees Must Weigh Company Coverage Against Medicare Plan

docs.abstract: Many retirees are weighing company coverage against new Medicare drug insurance program; many companies are sending retirees notices that if they cancel their current prescription drug coverage, company will cancel medical coverage as well; Louis A deBottari, Boeing retiree who received such a letter, says he will continue to use company's drug insurance instead of switching to Medicare plan; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Retirees are now weighing the benefits of coverage given to them by their former employers against the new Medicare drug insurance program that begins in January.

byline.original: By MILT FREUDENHEIM and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME countries set health care spending policies through national legislation. In California, they do it through television advertising. It is almost impossible this week to turn on a television set without seeing an advertisement paid for by the major drug companies that is pushing one plan to let uninsured people qualify for prescription drug discounts, while vigorously opposing a competing proposal backed by unions and consumer groups.

headline.main: Pricing Drugs As if They Were Cars

docs.snippet: Within the U.S., it turns out that drug prices are set in the same way that used-car prices are set: the better you are at negotiating, the less you pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the fourth day of a transit strike in Philadelphia, Gov. Edward G. Rendell said he would begin prodding the two sides to reach an agreement if talks remain stalled through the weekend. The cost of health care has been the main sticking point in negotiations, with the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority demanding that union members pay 5 percent of their health premiums. In a statement, Mr. Rendell, a Democrat, said he considered it ''only fair'' that union workers pay for some of their health insurance, though he stopped short of endorsing management's proposal. James Dao (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Governor Speaks Out On Strike

docs.abstract: Pennsylvania Gov Edward G Rendell anounces on fourth day of Philadelphia transit strike that he will begin urging Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority and union members to reach agreement if talks remain stalled on Nov 7; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration threatened Tuesday to veto a huge budget bill if Congress withdrew $10 billion set aside for health insurance companies participating in the Medicare program. The veto threat came as the Senate began work on the omnibus bill, intended to cut $39 billion from federal benefit programs over the next five years. Democrats said the savings would be dwarfed by tax cuts that Republicans planned to pass in coming months.

headline.main: Congress Is Warned of Veto If Insurance Funding Is Cut

docs.snippet: The Bush administration threatened Tuesday to veto a huge budget bill if Congress withdrew $10 billion set aside for health insurance companies participating in the Medicare program.     The veto threat came as the Senate began work on the omnibus...

docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about Wal-Mart's efforts to provide health care to more employees misstated the surname of the patient at a clinic in a Wal-Mart store near Orlando, Fla. He is Josh Hashbarger, not Reyes.
